text: Title Card: The Beginning

Almost a montage: A huge black SNAKE slips along a tree branch. The Snake’s head whispers into EVE’s ear. A hand, Eve’s, picks an apple from a tree. She takes a bi Grins. Passes it to ADAM. (They are both tastefully naked would not make them white people.) Adam also takes a bite And then he grins lecherously at Eve. Tasteful blackout.. Time lapse... A rumble of supernatural THUNDER! An angel in white robes (AZIRAPHALE but we can’t see his face), holding a flaming sword, gestures impressively tow an exit gate: they have to leave...

The Garden is walled. Inside, a perfect place of greenery Outside, something more like a desert or an African plain Adam and Eve, now wearing leaf-based clothes, in tears, a running, desperately away from the Garden. Adam is holdin something we cannot see. Eve is pregnant. Animals roar...

location: ON THE WALL OF THE GARDEN OF EDEN

text: Watching Adam and Eve leave, are the angel, AZIRAPHALE, a beside him, on a tree, a very, very large black SNAKE. Th Snake HISSES loudly.

Sorry. What was that? The snake TRANSMUTES into a male Demon. He’s dressed in robes, as opposed to the Angel’s white robes, and his eye look like the eyes of a snake. (IF WE DO WINGS his are gr feathers, the angel’s are white.)
I said, Well, that one went down like a lead balloon.
Oh. Yes, it did, rather.
Bit of an overreaction, if you ask me. First offense and everything. And I can’t see what’s so bad about knowing the difference between good and evil, anyway.
It must BE bad. Otherwise you wouldn't have tempted them into it.
They just said, Get up there and make some trouble. So I did.
Obviously. You’re a demon. It’s what you do.
Not very subtle of Him, though. Fruit tree in the middle of a garden, with a don’t touch sign. If He really didn’t want them to eat the apples, He could have put it on the moon.
Best not to speculate. It’s all part of the ineffable plan. I don’t like the look of that weather. Low rumble of non-supernatural thunder on the horizon.
Didn't you have a flaming sword?
Er...
You did. It was flaming like anything. What happened to it?
Er...
Lost it, have you?
(mutters inaudibly) I gave it away.
You what?

I gave it away. They looked so miserable. And there are vicious animals, and it’s going to be cold out there, and she’s expecting already, and I said, here you go, flaming sword, don’t thank me, and don’t let the sun go down on you here.... I do hope I didn’t do the wrong thing.
You’re an angel. How can you do the wrong thing?
It’s been bothering me. In the distance, Adam uses the flaming sword on some poor lion. Aziraphale winces. NB it’s pronounced Azeerafail.
...I’ve been worrying too. What if I did the right thing, with the whole eat-the-apple business. A demon can get into a lot of trouble for doing the right thing. Funny if we both got it wrong, eh?

Not really. Not funny at all. The Thunderstorm begins in earnest.  TITLE CARD: ELEVEN YEARS AGO. Buddy Holly’s song “Every Day” plays, beginning with a ti tick tick and... Every day, it's a-getting closer...

Establishing shot of Aziraphale’s Bookshop. It’s a run-do Secondhand/antiquarian Bookshop of the kind you used to s lots of in London... INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOKSHOP - AFTERNOON AZIRAPHALE is answering the phone. He has not changed sin we saw him as an angel. He looks like a happy, affluent, book dealer. He’s a kind-looking gentleman whose sartoria style runs to bow-ties. He thinks a little tartan is nift and would use the world nifty with pride. His bookshop is chaotic, crowded, glorious, dusty. He is sitting at a tab at a desk piled high with books.

First edition of Gibbons’ Decline and Fall? Yes, I definitely have a set here somewhere. Six volumes, let me see, 1776... No, I don’t know where it is, but you’re welcome to come in and have a root around. And if I come across it, I could telephone you. He writes down a phone number.

Happy to help. He puts down the phone. Makes an “I’m a bit naughty but a profoundly lovable” face (a la Boris Johnson). Sits back his chair, returns to reading his copy of Gibbons’s Decli and Fall of the Roman Empire volume I, and drops the phon number in the bin.

It’s 7:30pm in Midsummer, the streetlights are going on, people are leaving their offices. One person is going to work: CROWLEY is wearing stylish very black sunglasses, a very nice suit. He is carrying a clipboard and a Thermos flask. His hairstyle is perfect for somewhere around a decade a He glances around a little theatrically. He puts on a day orange donkey jacket. He hangs an Identity Card on a lanyard around his neck. T he walks in to the BT Tower building lobby.
A security desk. Behind it, a bored female SECURITY GUARD does a crossword.
Rataway Pest Control.
I thought your lot weren’t due in until tomorrow morning.
Preliminary inspection. Traps go down tomorrow. My job’s to tell them where.
Bloody everywhere. I’ve never seen anything like it. I put down a tuna sandwich yesterday, never saw it again. Health and safety closed off the upper floors as a health hazard until you lot get here.
Crowley and another Security Guard are in the lift.
Sunglasses?
It’s my eyes.
I'm afraid I’m not going to be able to let you wander around on your own up here. Unescorted. Lot of communications go through here. All the mobile phone services, for a start.
Is that right?

The lift dings, and Crowley and the Guard step out. The f is empty. Night lighting. But we hear a SCRATCHING. Crowley looks around. Every surface is alive. A nose. Sharp teeth. A twitch of tail. RATS. Hundreds of them! Tiny sinister red eyes glow at us from all over. A beat, then they move -- they are coming towards us! The Guard steps back into the lift.
You know. I’m just going to wait here.
I don’t blame you. The lift door closes. Crowley walks forward. He takes out thermos, unscrews the top, pours himself a cup of steamin tea. And Crowley... smiles.
Beautiful job! Thank you all, so much men! A lady rat chirps angrily.
And, yes, obviously, ladies too. Nice job! You can all go home. And, yeah, stay cool.

He walks into a room filled with computer and BT equipmen All of it old-fashioned and out-dated equipment: the computers of yesteryear, and some cables. Lots of green and red lights flashing. Crowley pours his tea onto the unit. Then he pours the re of the tea from the thermos. All around the room CONSOLE Lights start to flicker. Something electronic buzzes.
Crowley enters the lift.
That was quick.
Left something back in the van.
CONSOLE Lights flickering. And then they start to GO OUT.
Crowley walks out of the lobby. On the pavement is a BUSINESSMAN on an old-fashioned pre-smartphone phone.

No, I understand. That’s why we have to close this now. So. Seventy grand. Our final offer. What do you say? And then he shakes the phone. Tries redialling, and we fo Crowley, who is taking off his jacket, past people on the pavement, a WOMAN,
No Arthur, you can pick me up here. I’m on the corner of... can you hear me? Hello? ...a TEENAGE BOY...

Look, I know I kissed her at the party. But I mean, that doesn’t mean I wanted to dump you. I’m really sorry. I’m really hullo? Hullo? Over this we can hear a telecom voice saying “We are sorr All circuits are busy.” And Crowley is smiling. What a wonderful day. Checks his beautiful black watch, and stresses a little. He’s late. He reaches his car, a beautiful vintage Bentley Sports C and pulls out onto the road.

He fumbles with the radio, and to the beat of either KILL QUEEN by QUEEN, or a seriously rocking cover of Buddy Hol “EVERY DAY”, he starts driving through the London streets ridiculous speeds. And as he drives, we see a Title Card with GOOD OMENS on and hear our NARRATOR:
Good Omens. Being a Narrative of Certain Events occurring in the last eleven years of human history, in strict accordance, as shall be shown, with The Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Agnes Nutter.
A small country churchyard. Possibly ruined. Rather creep We move through it slowly... It’s misty, and brrr.

It wasn’t a dark and stormy night. It should have been, but that’s the weather for you. But don’t let the fog, with rain later, fool you. Just because it’s a mild night doesn’t mean the forces of evil weren’t abroad. They’re everywhere. That’s the whole point. And by now we’ve reached two very evil-looking gentlemen, standing in the shadows. One squat and monstrous, LIGUR. tall, thin and monstrous, HASTUR. They have something -- box-shaped object -- behind them, in the dark shadows. Hastur has been hand-rolling a tobacco cigarette. He puts in his mouth, lights it with a flame from his fingertip. the flame’s light, we get a good look at them. They don’t have horns, they wear vintage suits and shabby raincoats, but they aren’t human. Weird eyes.  Skin like frogs, or pitted with terrible acne. They are trying hard to pass for human, but not even the fog is helping.
Take these two. They’ve been lurking in the fog for an hour. But they've been pacing themselves, and could lurk until dawn.
Gissa drag. Hastur hands him the cigarette.
Bugger this for a lark. He should have been here an hour ago.
His name is Hastur. He is a Duke of Hell.
You trust him?
Ligur. Also a Duke of Hell.
Nope.
Be a funny old world if Demons went around trusting each other. What’s he calling himself these days?
Crowley.
Back to Titles and Rocking Music. Crowley, still speeding looks in his rear-view mirror. A POLICE CAR, behind him, turns on its blue light.
No. And now the SIREN starts.
I do not have time for this.  10.
Two POLICE OFFICERS are thrilled to be doing a high-speed chase in the fog. No, really they are.
The nutter’s doing a hundred and ten. In the fog. You know what this means?
We get to do a hundred and fifteen. Brilliant. What the hell kind of car is that?
Vintage Bentley, I think. Come on, nutter. Pull over.
The noise of the siren is starting to get to him. Crowley irritated, snaps his fingers.
(into police radio) In pursuit of a speeding vehicle. Vintage Bentley. And we're... The Police Car engine makes a whining sound, and then it slows down and stops.
We're having mechanical problems. Over.

The police car, on the side of the road. Fog. The car’s steaming. They open the bonnet. We move from police officer to police officer: they look horrified and confused. And now we look at the engine. Where the engine ought to be is just GREEN GOO, steaming bubbling gently.  11.
Ligur and Hastur, still lurking. Hastur crushes the dog-e under his foot. We can see a little more of the object be him. A car's headlights approach in the fog.
Here he comes now, the flash bastard.
What's that he's drivin'?
It's a car. A horseless carriage. Didn't they have them last time you was up here?
They had a man walking in front with a red flag.
They've come on a bit since then. A car door SLAMs.
What’s he like?

Crowley? Been up here too long. And he wears sunglasses, even when he dunt need to. We look from Hastur’s TOAD-LIKE eyes to Ligur’s FLY-EYES, we suspect why Crowley might want to wear Sunglasses. Crowley is Sauntering up the path. He stops. They stare a him.
All hail Satan.
All hail Satan.
Er. Hi guys. Sorry I'm late, but, well, you know how it is on the A40 at Denham, and then I tried to cut up towards Chorleywood --  12. Hastur interrupts him.
Now we art all here, we must recount the Deeds of the Day.
("we do? Oh, I remember this.”) Of course. Deeds. Yeah.

I have tempted a priest. As he walked down the street and saw the pretty girls in the sun, I put Doubt into his mind. He would have been a saint, but within a decade we shall have him. Ligur makes approving guttural throaty noises, as if this the best thing he’s ever heard.
(politely) Nice one.

I have corrupted a politician. I let him think a tiny bribe would not hurt. Within a year we shall have him. Hatsur hisses approval. They stare at Crowley. Him next. that’s good, because he has the BEST one...
You'll like this. We look at their faces and know that they won’t.
I brought down every London area mobile phone network tonight. There is a baffled silence.
Yes?  13.
It wasn’t easy. I had to send rats into the BT Tower, and I had to pour tea into the network controller, while the backup system was offline for maintainance...
And what exactly has that done to secure souls for our master?
Oh come on! Fifteen million pissed- off people? Who take it out on each other? Who take it out on everyone else? Ruined days. Ruined nights. The knock-on effects are incalculable...
It’s not... craftsmanship.

Head office don’t seem to mind. They love me down there. Guys, times are changing. So, what’s up? Hastur reaches down and picks up the object at his feet. kind of wicker basket. He hands it to Ligur, who grins unpleasantly...
This is.
No.
Yes.
Already?
Yes.
And it’s up to me to...?
Yes.  14.
You know. This sort of... well, it really isn’t my scene.
Your scene. Your starring role. Take it.
Like you said. Times are changing.
They're coming to an end, for a start.
Why me?
They love you down there. And what an opportunity. Ligur here would give his right arm to be you tonight.
Somebody's right arm, anyway. Hastur has produced a clipboard.
Sign here. Crowley writes A. J. Crowley on the clipboard.

No. Your real name. Crowley uses the tip of his finger, and writes a sigil wh burns where he’s touched it. The entire sheet of paper go up like flash paper. Ligur holds out the large wicker basket. It could be a do basket, but it’s the wrong shape... Crowley looks dejecte
Now what?
You will receive instructions. Why so glum? The moment we have been working for all these centuries is at hand!  15.
Centuries.
Our moment of eternal triumph awaits! Crowley is forcing a smile. It does not convince anyone.
Triumph.
And you will be a tool of that glorious destiny!
Glorious. Tool. Yeah. He takes the basket from Ligur
Okay. I'll, er, be off then. Shall I? Get it over with. Not that I want to get it over with. Obviously. But you know me. Keen. Two implacable Demon faces. Crowley backs away down the path.
So I'll be popping along. See you guys ar- see you. Er. Great. Fine. Ciao. In the mist. We hear the Bentley car door slam.
Wossat mean. Ciao?
It's Italian. It means “food”.
Aziraphale walks in. The Waitress points to his favourite table, kept free for him. The Sushi Chef behind the counter says,  16.
(in japanese) Here is a selection of your favourite rolls, Honoured Aziraphale-San. The waitress, who puts them, along with a cup of steaming tea, on the table, and bows. Aziraphale bows back.
(In fluent Japanese) You honour me. Thank you Suzuki- San. He sits at his table. Smiles as he eats his first nibble. Life is good.
Crowley is driving. He looks miserable, stressed and upse The mystery basket is on the back seat. He turns on the radio.
Oh. Shit....
And the FT index finished up 5 points today, after vigorous trading.
..-Ohshitohshitohshit. Why me?
Because you earned it, Crowley. Didn't you?
Leave it to me, Lord.
That is what we are doing, Crowley. But if anything goes wrong, then those involved will suffer greatly. Even you, Crowley. Especially you. Crowley nods. He’s terrified.

Here are your instructions.  17. And Crowley FREEZES for a moment, as information is downloaded directly into his brain. (Perhaps, from behind dark glasses, his eyes could glow for a moment.) A bad idea to do this while he’s driving, because a LORRY heading towards him in the fog. At the last moment, he gets his brain back, and TWISTS TH STEERING WHEEL HARD, slamming out of the Lorry’s way, a maneuver that throws the wicker basket across the back se And now, for the first time, we can see what it is: a wic bassinet. And the sleeping NEWBORN BABY inside it opens i eyes, and it WAILS... TITLE CARD: Bringing about Armageddon can be dangerous. TITLE CARD: Please do not attempt this in your own home. Now we get the rest of the TITLE CREDITS. And these occur, being dealt out while we in THE NARRATOR’S WORLD. A darkened space, like a studio or a warehouse belonging rich madman who can afford anything he wants. We can see a big, beautiful, globe of the world, and a newspaper on a table. Other things that are on the table right now include a pack of cards and a little wind-up dinosaur skeleton. A hand comes out of the darkness, and starts to rotate th globe. Our narrator is authoritative and reassuring: the voice of history, of science, of wisdom. As he speaks things ANIMATE: We see, first, the BIG BANG, SCIENTISTS. The CERN particle accelerator.

Current theories on the creation of the Universe state that it came into being about twenty billion years ago. By the same token the earth itself is generally supposed to be about four and a half billion years old. (beat) These dates are incorrect. Now we see ancient scholars, working with abacuses, scrol and scraps of parchment...  18. NARRATOR (CONT’D) Medieval Jewish scholars put the date of the Creation at 3760 BC. Greek Orthodox theologians put Creation as far back as 5508 BC. (beat) Also incorrect. Now, Ussher and his assistants, with a huge genealogical of the line of Adam, and how long everyone lived... NARRATOR (CONT’D) Archbishop James Ussher claimed that the Heaven and the Earth were created in 4004 BC. One of his aides took the calculation further, and was able to announce that the Earth was created on Sunday the 21st of October, 4004 BC, at 9.00 a.m. This too was incorrect. By almost a quarter of an hour. We're back in the Narrator’s space. His face is in the shadows, but he’s talking to us directly. NARRATOR (CONT’D) This proves two things: Firstly, that God moves in extremely mysterious ways. God does not play dice with the universe; He plays an ineffable game of His own devising, which might be compared to playing poker in a pitch-dark room, for infinite stakes, with a Dealer who won't tell you the rules. (beat) Secondly, the Earth's a Libra. The Narrator leans into the light and picks up the newspa Reads to us: NARRATOR (CONT’D) The astrological prediction for Libra in the 'Your Stars Today' column of the Tadfield Advertiser. LIBRA. You may be feeling run down and always in the same old daily round. A friend is important to you. You may be vulnerable to a stomach upset today, so avoid salads. Help could come from an unexpected quarter.  19.

A green Morris Traveller is driving cautiously along the outside the hospital. Inside the Car are Deirdre Young an her husband, Arthur Young. He is in his forties, she is i her late thirties and hugely pregnant. This is her first child. But everything’s very normal...
This was perfectly correct on every count except for the bit about the salads.
Are we there yet? Arthur? Seven minutes apart.
It's definitely this way. It’s just the roads look all different int he dark...
The nuns said to come in when they were seven to ten minutes apart.
It’s a bit, um. Well. Nuns.
Do we have any egg and cress sandwiches? Mrs Young reaches for a sandwich, and as she does so, has contraction... A Sirening MOTORCADE zooms past them -- an ambulance, followed by three black cars.
Arthur. Just follow them.

Suddenly Rapid-cutting, ultra-adrenaline: The Ambulance i going at speed. In it is HARRIET DOWLING, the movie-star- beautiful wife of the American Cultural Attache to London Very pregnant. Standing near her, and being thrown around TWO SECRET SERVICE AGENTS. Holding a video screen, and a video camera. It’s a pre-skype Video hookup from the old days.  20. On the video screen we can see TAD (THADDEUS J) DOWLING, cultural attache, back in the US, soon to be presidential hopeful, in a White House meeting. He’s talking to her:
Breathe, honey. Just breathe.
I am breathing, goddammit, Tad. Why aren’t you here?
Honey. I’m with you. I’m just also here with the President.
Hey Harriet. Sorry we had to borrow your husband.
Hon, I’d better get back to the strategy conference.
You are meant to be with me, you useless sonofabitch (Contraction).
Honey, you're going to the best place we could find at short notice. The, uh...
St Beryl’s Convent Birthing Hospital, sir.

St Beryl’s. Right. Honey, you just keep on having the baby. I’1l be right here with you. Birth is the single most joyous co-experience that two human beings can share, and I’m not going to miss a second of it.
Tad. If we can return to the matter in hand?

I’1ll get back to you honey. And the screen goes blank. Mrs Dowling bites back some re impressive swearing.  21. INT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT - NIGHT An old convent, part of which has been converted into a s birthing hospital. We are looking at a dozen NUNS. The Mo Superior is facing them. The SATANIC nature of the place given away by the upside-down Cross on the wall beside th Mother Superior.
The child of the American Cultural Attache. Everything is ready. Tonight, it begins.
Excuse me Mother Superior but I was wondering where the other baby was going to come from, not the American baby, I mean that’s obvious, that’s just the birds and the bees, but the, you know --

Mr Crowley is on his way with our dark master to be, Sister Mary Loquacious. Now. We are Nuns of the Chattering Order of Saint Beryl. And tonight is what our order was created for. We can hear the ambulance Siren drawing up outside. MOTHER SUPERIOR (CONT’D) Places! And the Nuns begin to move, and as they do, they begin to chat to each other, each one saying whatever’s on her min Mother Superior reaches out and tips the upside down cros right-way up. And she SMILES. EXT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT - NIGHT Behind the Ambulance and the Motorcade of Black Cars, we a Green Morris Traveller.

Right.  22. INT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT RECEPTION - NIGHT We watch as two things are happening at the same time. Harriet Dowling is wheeled in, followed by a secret servi man with a video camera, OTHER SECRET SERVICE MEN saying things like “Clear!” into their earpieces, and all is commotion... Meanwhile Mr and Mrs Young walk up to the front desk. He’ carrying a little suitcase.
Excuse me. Deirdre Young. I phoned. Contractions now five minutes apart.
Welcome to St Beryl’s. We’re all ready for you. Room Three. Deirdre turns to Mr Young, takes the Suitcase.
Obviously Arthur will be with me, while I’m in labour...
I don’t think so. We believe fathers just... complicate the process for everybody.
But-- Mr Young looks relieved.
Not going to argue with Nuns. Nurses. Know what they’re doing, Deirdre. I'll be. Um. He produces his pipe, from his pocket. Deirdre glares at him as she is swept off in a storm of nuns...

EXT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT - NIGHT Mr Young walks out into the driveway to smoke his pipe. H tamps down some tobacco -- clearly a man for whom the rit of smoking are more important than actually smoking itsel He starts looking for his lighter...

It may help to understand human affairs if you notice that most of the great triumphs and tragedies of history are caused, not by people being fundamentally good or fundamentally bad, but by people being fundamentally people. And a Vintage Bentley pulls up. Crowley gets out, grabs t carry-cot, and heads towards us.
Has it started yet?
They made me go out.
Any idea how long we've got?
I think we were, er, getting on with it, Doctor.
Got it. What room is she in?
We're in Room Three. INT. ST BERYL’S CONVENT CORRIDOR - NIGHT We're in the Corridor. Looking at Sister Mary, from the P of the baby in the carrycot.
Is that him?
Yup.
Only I'd expected funny eyes. Or teensy-weensy little hoofikins. Or a widdle tail.  24. She's taken the baby out of the carrier and is turning it over...
It's definitely him.
Fancy me holding the Antichrist. And counting his little toesy- wosies... Do you look like your daddy? I bet you do. I bet you look like your daddywaddykins....
He doesn’t. Take him up to Room three.

Watching Sister Mary outside the room, with a three on it from further down the corridor the Secret Service Men gla at her suspiciously. Mary goes in, with the antichrist ba to the room in which Deirdre Young is asleep. Mrs Young has BABY B in a bassinet sleeping soundly besid her. Sister Mary carefully takes the ID tag off the Young’s ba and just as carefully attaches it to the Antichrist Baby. Sister Mary looks at the two babies. They look quite simi don’t they? She puts on the kettle. A HESITANT KNOCK on the door. Mr Young.
Has it happened yet? I’m the father. The husband. Both.
Ooh yes. Congratulations. Your lady wife’s asleep, poor pet. Mr Young looks down at the babies. Baby B and the Antichr baby.
Twins? Nobody said anything about twins.  25.

Oh, no! This one's yours. The other one's... someone else's. Just looking after him. No, this one's definitely yours, your ambassadorship. From the top of his head to the tips of his hoofywoofies - which he hasn't got.
All, er, present and correct, is he?
Oh, yes. Normal. Very, very normal. You don't have much of an accent. Have you been over here long?
About ten years. The job moved, you see, and I had to move with it.
It must have been very different where you were before. She's making tea.
Er...
Taller buildings, for one thing.
There’s the Alliance and Leicester offices. (he’s given tea) Oh, thank you.
And I expect you go to a lot of HER garden parties.
Well, fetes mainly. Deidre makes jam for them, you know. And I sometimes have to help with the White Elephant.
I expect they're tribute. I read where these foreign potentates give her majesty all sorts of things. (MORE )
Are you sure you want tea? There’s actual coffee in one of the vendible machines on the second floor.
Tea’s fine.
My word. You have gone native, haven't you...?

Everything in this delivery room is fast-cut, with adventurous camera moves and POUNDING MUSIC: we see the s on foreheads, sharp lighting. It is a much bigger deliver room, which is good because it has to fit a lot of people have our SECRET SERVICE MEN, one of them with his video camera, one of them holding up a small screen, a couple o MINOR US OFFICIALS, nurse nuns, and Harriet Dowling, in t process of giving birth to Baby A, loudly and angrily.
The Eagle is Landing. Repeat. The Eagle is Landing. Two nuns give each other significant looks. One of them, Sister Teresa Garrulous, nods and leaves. More POUNDING MUSIC.

An intimate classical concert, somewhere nice, like an ar museum. A String Quintet (two cellos) is playing Schubert’s Strin Quintet. The melody washes over a beaming and well-fed Aziraphale, sitting happily in the well-dressed audience, at perfect peace with the world.
Pounding music. Sister Teresa Garrulous isn’t actually running down the corridors, but she is moving as fast as can, scanning every open room as she passes...
Sister Mary is presenting Mr Young with a selection of pi iced biscuits.
Now these are what we call “bis- cuits”, but you’ll be looking at them and going (fingerquotes) “cookies”!

No, I definitely call them biscuits. BLAM! The door opens, Mrs Young stirs in her bed, and Sis Teresa enters, to see: Sleeping Baby B... Mr Young... Sleeping the Antichrist Baby... Sister Mary... Sleeping Mrs Young... Her puzzled glance returns to the babies... Sister Teresa looks furious, but only for a second. She looks at Sister Mary and WINKS. Sister Mary points at Baby B and WINKS. Sister Teresa looks happy, wheels the bassinet with baby it out of the door, and TAKES OFF DOWN THE CORRIDOR WITH IT... Sister Mary smiles happily. FREEZE FRAME. The Narrator walks in front of the frozen frame, holding long pointer.
As methods of human communication go, the wink is quite versatile. For example, Sister Teresa’s wink meant,  28. Sister Teresa comes through the door, furious:

Where the hell have you been? We're ready to make the switch, and here's you in the wrong room with the Adversary, Destroyer of Kings, Angel of the Bottomless Pit, Great Beast that is called Dragon, Prince of This World, Father of Lies, Spawn of Satan, and Lord of Darkness, drinking tea. Do you realize I've nearly been shot?
And, as far as she was concerned, Sister Mary's answering wink meant: Sister Mary looks up from her tea, and says, sharp, sexy out of character (the voice could be done by Sister Teres

This child is the Adversary, Destroyer of Kings, Angel of the Bottomless Pit, Great Beast that is called Dragon, Prince of This World, Father of Lies, Spawn of Satan and Lord of Darkness. But I cannot speak freely now because there's this outsider here.
Sister Mary, on the other hand, had thought that the orderly's wink was more on the lines of: Sister Teresa is now voiced by Sister Mary.

Well done, that Sister Mary - switched over the babies all by herself. Now indicate to me the superfluous child and I shall remove it and let you get on with your tea with his Royal Excellency the American Culture.
And therefore her own wink had meant:  29.

There you go, dearie; that one’s Baby B, now take him away and leave me to chat to his Excellency. He’s telling me all about the Queen and her elephants. Back to reality: SISTER MARY LOQUACIOUS (CONT’D) Have you picked a name for him yet?
Sister Teresa hands Baby B to Mrs Dowling:
Here’s your little man back. All cleaned up and weighed. The Secret Service men edge forward nervously. One is sti filming: Mrs Dowling shows the baby to his camera.
Look, honey. Our son.

He’s beautiful, hon. What a little tyke, huh? Seeing him makes me understand what’s important in life. It’s not work. I’m going to teach him to play baseball, and on Sundays we'll go fishing and, sorry hon, that’s someone on the other line. The awkwardness of the moment is increased as the Mother Superior, whom we had not seen enter the room, says, ominously:
You must name the child.
Well, we were going to name him Thaddeus, after his pop. And his pop’s pop...
Damien’s an excellent name.
Damien Dowling? Too alliterative.  30.
Warlock, then. It’s an old English name. A good name. Harriet looks down at little Warlock.
Hello, Warlock.
Deirdre Young is still asleep, as is the Antichrist Baby. Sister Mary is getting into the naming.
Damien? No, I had fancied something more, well, traditional. We've always gone in for good simple names in our family.
Cain. Very modern sound, Cain, really.
Hmm.
Or there's always .. . well, there's always Adam.
Adam? Hm. Adam... And at that moment, the baby wakes, and opens its eyes, a starts to cry... and the baby, waking, wakes Deirdre Youn
Oh. Give him here, George. Come on little one... She reaches for the crying baby and prepares to breastfee
You know, Deirdre, I think he looks like an Adam.
Crowley has a hands free calling system: He’s driving and says,  31.
Call Aziraphale.
Calling Aziraphale.
We are sorry. All circuits are busy. We are sorry. All circuits are...
Aziraphale enters, humming Schubert. Hangs up his coat. The phone on the desk rings... Aziraphale glares at it. H wants to let it ring. Then he picks it up.
I'm afraid we're quite definitely closed.
Crowley is standing in the last village phonebox in Engla to have a working payphone in it.
It’s me. We have to talk. It’s the Big One.
Crowley. “The Big One”. Really? Isn’t that a little melodramatic, even for you?
Don’t be like that, Aziraphale. I'll explain when I see you. Usual place. Usual time.
What’s the usual time?
Whenever I get up.
Ten thirty?
One-ish.  32.
When you say “The Big One..” you DO mean...?
Armageddon. Yeah. He breaks the connection. INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - NIGHT Aziraphale looks like someone’s punched him in the stomac
Oh dear.
A dusty red-painted truck rumbles along a dusty road that little more than a track. African music, African animals. beautiful establishing shot. Title card: I

A quiet, perfect village. Children run, laughing through streets. A woman sits beside her wares in the market. And there’s a gunshot... -..no. It’s a truck, backfiring. We see it limping throug the main road, and then it makes some noises trucks shoul not make, and STOPS completely. The DRIVER gets out and lifts the trunk: thick smoke come out. An African PASSER-BY walks over.
That does not look good. The driver looks up, and we discover that she is a white woman in her 20s with the most amazing flame-red hair. Sh has an American accent. She’s called SCARLETT. She is WAR
Nope. It’s not. Is there a bar around here? Somewhere I can make a phone call?  33.

Over there. But you can’t just leave your truck here. Without a look back, she walks over to the bar... INT. AFRICAN BAR — DAY Scarlett opens a bottle of beer by casually slamming it a her hand against the counter, and drains it. The Bartende a bored African woman in her mid 30s.
I got a truck. The Engine’s shot. Anyone around here I can talk to?
Only Nathan. But he’s gone back to Kaunda to his father-in-law’s farm.
When’s he coming back?
A week. Perhaps two weeks.
The Passer-by walks around the truck. Then he peeks insid There are a lot of boxes in there. And the boxes are all stencilled with WARNINGS. High explosive. Ammunition. Gun Rocket launchers...
A elderly payphone in the corner. Scarlett is talking.

Yeah, I know you paid for the shipment. You'll just have to wait another two weeks to start your war. There are TWO MEN sitting at a corner table, having an ea going conversation, drinking and laughing. SCARLETT (CONT’D) Don’t be like that. No, you listen to me. No. (MORE )

SCARLETT (CONT’D) You may have bought the equipment, but it begins when I get there... Really? REALLY? She puts down the phone, sits down at the table with the SCARLETT (CONT’D) Hey. When was the last war in these parts? The two men look at each other.
I don’t think we’ve ever had one.
We don’t go in for things like that here.
No! 1952. In the town square...
That was not a war. And they both felt a bit silly when they woke up... Scarlett gets up and walks out of the bar...
She looks out at the lazy African paradise.
Oh, what the hell. I needed a holiday anyway. TIME SHIFT...

It’s 24 hours later. An explosion rocks the street. A GRO OF MEN in improvised uniforms come charging down the stre A Rattling of sub-machine gun fire takes them out. They f A WOUNDED BOY behind them lobs a grenade... We follow the grenade behind improvised sandbags. The PEO BACK THERE see the grenade, and look horrified, as it blo up... We look at the Corpses on the street.  35. And then we see the Empty Truck. Five Women, one of them the Bartender, are up on the truc They have a rocket launcher.
If the Rebels want War, we will give them war, my sisters...
A busy African airport. Scarlett, not a hair out of place talking to a an African businessman in the lounge.
..+-which is why microeconomics is much more interesting than people believe. And what about you, Miss?
You know, I think maybe it’s time for a new profession... I think I’d like to be a journalist.
An agony auntie?
A war correspondent. EXT. ST JAMES’S PARK DUCKPOND - MORNING It’s morning in St James’ Park. It feels like a spy movie Our narrator is sitting on the park bench. He is eating a sandwich.

They say the ducks in St James’s park are so used to being fed by secret agents, that they’ve developed Pavlovian reactions to them. We pull back from him. There are people around the pond, pretending that they are not secret agents having clandes meetings. We can see a Russian and an American having a meeting, a British agent and a Chinese, a French and a Brazilian. In each case, they are pretending to feed the ducks.  36.
(tossing black bread) Rudnitsky’s gone triple.
(cucumber sandwich) If the treaty is signed, it will have global repercussions...
(baguette) We will match their offer...

The Russian cultural attache’s black bread is particularly sought after by the more discerning duck. Crowley and Aziraphale have been meeting here for several hundred years. Aziraphale is tossing his breadcrust to a drake. The drak pecks at it, then squawks, and DIES. Crowley has come up behind Aziraphale. They talk without looking at each other, like the other spies do.
Really, my dear. Was that necessary?
Sorry. The drake RETURNS TO LIFE, quacks and paddles off.
We knew something was going on, of course. I’ve made enquiries. An American diplomat. Really? As if Armagedden were a cinematographic show you wished to sell in as many countries as possible.
The Earth and all the Kingdoms thereof. Aziraphale looks at Crowley for the first time.
We will win, of course.  37.
You really believe that?
Obviously. Heaven finally triumphs over hell. It’s all going to be rather lovely. Crowley starts walking through the park. Aziraphale reluctantly follows him.
Out of interest, how many first class composers do your lot have in Heaven? Because Mozart’s one of ours. Beethoven. Schubert. All the Bachs...
They have already written their music...
And you'll never hear it again. No more Albert Hall. No more Glyndebourne. No more proms. No Compact Disks. Just celestial harmonies.
Oh dear.

And that’s just the start of what you'll lose if you win. No more fascinating little restaurants where they know you. No gravlax with dill sauce. No more old bookshops. No more Regency Silver Snuffboxes.
But after we win, life will be better for everybody.
You'll be about as happy with a harp as I'll be with a pitchfork.
We don’t play harps.  38.
And we don’t use pitchforks. You know what I mean.
But it has to happen. The Four Horsemen will ride out. The Seas will turn to blood...

The seas are fine just as they are. It’s where your sushi comes from. They've reached Crowley’s Bentley. He’s parked it on the Mall, somewhere you can’t park. It already has a wheelcla on it, and a Traffic Warden is walking around it, writing things down in his notebook, because this is the past, wh they had notebooks.
We've got about a decade. Then it’s all over. You have to help me.
No.
I’m serious. It’s the end of the world we're talking about. Not some little temptation I've asked you to cover for me while you’re in Edinburgh for the festival. You can’t just say no.
No.
We can do something. I’ve got an idea.
I. Am. Not. Interested. A breath. Crowley is about to fall apart. But he pulls himself together.
Fair enough. Let’s have lunch. I still owe you one from... Aziraphale glares at him. Then softens...  39.
Paris. 1793.
Oh, yes. The Reign of Terror. Was that one of yours or one of ours? They get in to the car... The WHEELCLAMPS VANISH.
Can't recall. Quite a nice restaurant though. The Traffic Warden, who is looking triumphant, is startle when his notebook bursts into flames as the Bentley drive away.
I didn’t mean to do that.
That was me. I thought your people invented them.
Really? I thought they were yours.
We pan across a restaurant. It’s a fancy restaurant. Dry and liquid nitrogen. Molecular Gastronomy. It’s very fanc Aziraphale and Crowley are looking around.
Ah. Sorry about this. Under new management. Still the most expensive restaurant in London. Just now it’s molecular gastronomy. Apparently they use, er, molecules.
Not really my kind of thing.
What is your kind of thing?

Well, they always do a lovely high tea at the Ritz. Crowley sighs and turns around. They leave....  40. But we remain in the restaurant. We pan across until we m the owner of the restaurant... RAVEN SABLE, who is American, dressed in black, and has t kind of beard popularised by the late Roger Delgado, or failing that, Max Maven. He looks sinister without trying is FAMINE. Title Card: II Sable looks on with approval as a WAITER brings his dinin partner, FRANNIE, his accountant and Financial Manager, a nearly empty but beautiful plate...
Your main course, madam. Chicken froth, on a reduction of broccoli gel, with a mushroom foam. And the chef recommends this, first... He hands her a balloon...
What is it? It looks like a balloon.
A balloon filled with lavender- scented air. Inhale it, then eat your dinner.
I need another glass of wine.
Of course.
Bon appetite, Frannie. So. You saw the latest royalty statement? Frannie is hungry. The molecular gastronomy is lost on he
12 Million copies, Dr Sable.
C’mon. Eat hearty. Molecular gastronomy. Amazing, huh?
It’s a lot of copies...
I was thinking about this place. All the money these folks pay to stay hungry. Yeah. I think it’s time to expand.
A new line of diet books?

Much more than that. It’s time to go corporate. A chain of fast food outlets. Factories. The whole schmear. They are interrupted by SHERRYL, a FASHION MODEL. 41. Horrendously underweight. Beautiful but dear god how can human being be that thin...?

Uh. Dr Sable. I hope you don’t mind me interrupting you. But your book. It changed my life... Sherryl. Two Rs. And a Y. She puts the book down on the table. Sable’s photo cover -- “THE D-PLAN DIET.” And the subtitle “SLIM BEAUTIFUL -- TERMINALLY!” He signs, saying:
Why indeed? There. A quote from the book of the revelation of St John.
You don’t know how much this means to me. She backs away.
That girl looks like she’s starving to death.
She is. She’s dying of hunger right now. So. Corporate... Frannie has an ultrathin, ultralight black laptop. stabbing at it... is on the
She's  42.
Already on it. We can buy into Holdings (Holdings) Incorporated for the initial Lichtenstein toehold. We use the Cayman Islands as a... Dr Sable? Are you listening?
Sorry -- It just occurred to me. I’ve never seen a room full of rich people so hungry... EXT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - DAY Crowley and Aziraphale are heading down the pavement to t Book shop.
I have several very nice little Chateuneuf De Papes in the back. I picked up a dozen cases of them in 1921, and I still have a couple of bottles left, for special occasions.
Not very big on wine in Heaven, are they? Not going to get any more nice little Chateuneuf De Papes in Heaven. Or Single malt scotch. Or little cocktails with umbrellas.

I told you, Crowley. I’m not helping you. I’m not interested. This is purely social. I’m an angel. You’re a demon. We’re hereditary enemies. Get thee behind me, foul fiend! He unlocks the door to the bookshop.
After you.
WHITE is in his twenties. He’s beautiful, in a dirty sort way. Everything about him, overalls, face, hair, is sligh grimy... He’s mopping a deck of an oil tanker... FREEZE o his face.  43.

He’s called White, or Albus, or Chalky, or Snowy. He’s had lots of interesting jobs in lots of interesting places... He’s helped design the petrol engine, plastics and the ring-pull can... He can turn his hand to anything, Mr White. Title Card: III White is walking through the Tanker’s decks. He passes th Captain’s Cabin: SHOT, CAPTAIN in bed, a hand releases an empty bottle to floor of the cabin. It rolls away and back. White passes a toilet. The NOISES of someone having a miserable time being sick emerge as he passes. White walks through the galley, where the SECOND MATE is passing the time by tossing peanuts into the air and catc them in his mouth. Or failing to catch them...

The captain is drunk in his cabin. The first mate is sick with a tummy bug. The second mate is in the galley. And that doesn’t matter, because the tanker is almost entirely automated. White reaches a door marked RESTRICTED ACCESS. The door swings open as he gets there.
There’s almost nothing left for a person can do. There’s a small Video Cam Unit in a corner, and a black a white monitor showing what’s going on inside. White ISN'T it.

WHITE walks to the Emergency Cargo Release Switch. It say “Insert KEY to Initialise EMERGENCY CARGO RELEASE”. He li a finger, thoughtfully, and twirls it in the air... As if in sympathy, lock turns, with no key in it.
White flicks the Cargo release switch into the RELEASE position.
(gently. Wistfully.) Oops.
We see the tanker below us, and, all around it a huge bla oil spill spreading out across the blue of the sea.
Afterwards, there was a huge amount of discussion as to whose fault it was. Neither the captain, the first or the second mate ever worked again...

The CAPTAIN, FIRST MATE and SECOND MATE are led off, daze in handcuffs, by POLICE... A tiny ship, a little steamer, as different as can possib be from the gleaming huge tanker, IS PASSING IN THE BACKGROUND. We zoom in on it....
But no-one gave any thought to Able Seaman White...

And there is White, eating crisps on the deck of the stea He tosses the empty crisp packet overboard. Behind him, w pan up to see, are rusting barrels each stencilled with WEEDKILLER -- TOXIC -- EXTREMELY DANGEROUS and Death’s heads...

Nobody ever does. EXT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - NIGHT Establishing shot of the outside of the shop. Soho...  45. INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP We move through the bookshop, listening to their conversation, until we reach the back room. There are a L of bottles of wines and spirits on the various surfaces, along with the teetering piles of books, the regency snuf box display. Crowley is Drunker than Aziraphale, but they both drunk.
So what. Exactly. Is. Your. Point?
My point is. My point is. The point I’m trying to make is... the dolphins. That’s my point.
Kind of fish.
Nononono, ‘S mammal. Your actual mammal. Difference is... Neither of them are very clear on the differences.
Mate out of water?
Don’t think so. Something about their young. Not the point. The point is. Their brains. He pours himself a huge glass of wine. It takes a lot to supernatural beings drunk.
What about their brains?
Big brains. That’s my point. Size of. Size of. Size of damn big brains. Not to mention whales. Brain city, whales, take it from me.
Kraken. Great big bugger. Supposed to rise to the surface right at the end, when the sea boils.  46.

That's my point, whole sea bubbling, dolphins, whales, everybody turning into bouillab, bouillab, fish soup. Not their fault. Same with gorillas. Whoops, they say, sky gone all red, stars crashing to ground, what they putting in the bananas these days?
All creatures great and small. Poor little, big...

And you know what makes it worse. When it’s all gone. You are going to have to deal with... ETERNITY! Crowley makes a huge gesture and sends a glass and conten flying. It smashes, loudly. Aziraphale gestures, and it reforms, slightly drunkenly.
Eternity? Crowley has found Aziraphale’s collection of Theatre programmes.

It won't be so bad at first. No Stephen Sondheim first nights in Eternity. But I’ve been assured He has a fondness for Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals. And He really loves the Sound of Music. Fancy spending Eternity watching that? You could literally climb every mountain over and over and over... Crowley walks around the back room...
I don't like it any more than you, but I told you. I can't disod - not do what I'm told. 'M a'nangel. I... (pause) I can't cope with this while 'm drunk. I'm going to sober up.
Me too.  47. He closes his eyes, and jerks: We watch the all bottles around the room refill with alcohol. Crowley and Azirapha look like people who have just become un-drunk and don’t it.

Mr Young drives the car up to the Main Door. Deirdre come out, with the baby. A bunch of chattering nuns wave goodb still chattering. Over this we hear Crowley and Aziraphal talking. INT. AZIRAPHALE’S BOOK SHOP - NIGHT Crowley is pacing, impatiently. Putting corks back into w bottles, perhaps. Aziraphale is agitated. They are both sober. And Aziraphale is coming over to the dark side.
Look! It’s not that I disagree with you. But I’m an angel. I’m not allowed to disobey.
You think I am?
You’re a demon. You love to disobey.
My people are only into disobedience in general terms. Not when it applies to them.
Even if I wanted to help, I couldn’t! I can't interfere with divine plans. Crowley gets an idea...
What about diabolical ones? My lot have put the baby in play, after all. You can interfere with that!
But... It's still part of the overall divine plan. It’s all part of the divine plan.  48.
Then you can't be certain that thwarting me isn't part of the divine plan too. I mean, you're supposed to thwart the wiles of the Evil One at every turn, aren't you?
Well...
You see a wile, you thwart. Am I right?
Broadly. Actually I encourage humans to do the actual --
The Antichrist is here. But birth is just the start. It's the upbringing that's important. It's the Influences. And the evil influences -- that’s all me!
If you put it that way, Heaven couldn't actually mind me thwarting you...
It'd be a real feather in your wing. Aziraphale looks at him, doubtfully. Then he reaches out hand, and Crowley and Aziraphale shake hands on it.
We'll be godfathers, sort of. Over- seeing his upbringing. He won’t be evil. He'll be normal.
You know, I'd never have thought of that. Godfathers. Well, I'll be damned.
It’s not that bad. Once you get used to it. We hear a crack of thunder...  49.

A storm has begun. There’s a motorcade, ready to take the Dowling baby away. Mrs Dowling comes out of the Door, wit the baby. We pull back: From the top of a nearby hill, Hastur steps from the shadows. The Mother Superior and Sister Grace Voluble runs up the hill.
Our Mission is done, Lord Hastur. The baby is in place.
No need for the convent any longer, then. Or for the Order.
I'm afraid I --
Your order is dissolved.
We're what?
Now hang on a moment. We did everything that was asked of us. What about our rewards?
You irritate me. You talk too much.

We are a chattering order. We say exactly what is on our mind, and right now, what’s on my mind is that you can’t treat us like -- Hastur reaches out and puts his hand over Sister Grace’s mouth, and squeezes. She dies. Hastur looks at the Mother Superior.
Do you want to tell them the order is dissolved? Or do you want them all to perish in the fire.

(shaken) Fire?  50. Hastur gestures. Lightning strikes the roof of the Hospit The Mother Superior looks at him, and then runs back down hill. Hastur begins to laugh, and it’s absorbed by the thunder. The lights of the fire brigade are coming...

We hold on the fallen body of the late Sister Grace Volub And then we move from her to the fallen bodies in the Afr Village Square. From there to Sherryl the supermodel from the restaurant, bed, dead. From there to dead fish, floating in an oil spill... And from there back to the Weedkiller boat, and we close on the death’s head on the POISON signs. The sign of the grinning skull. Title: IV Over all this:
And there’s a Fourth. He’s everywhere, and what he does is what he is. He isn’t waiting. He’s working. Although in a manner of speaking, he’s waiting for us all.

EXT. WARLOCK’S RESIDENCE - DAY It's fancy, and there are secret service men outside. We a Mary Poppins style NANNY walking towards the house, wit her back to us. The doorbell is pressed. The door is opened. And the Nann wearing dark glasses, reminds us of Crowley. She’s sexy a domineering.

I understand you need a nanny.  51. EXT. WARLOCK’S BACK DOOR - DAY The back door is opened. A saintly friar-like GARDENER, b victorian gaffer sideburns, angelic, with a spade, who perhaps reminds us a little of Aziraphale, possibly chewi grass-blade, raises his hat and says,
They do say as you moight be lookin’ for a gardener. EXT. WARLOCK’S RESIDENCE GARDEN - DAY
A small boy in a garden. Brother Francis, the gardener, i feeding the birds... YOUNG WARLOCK, aged about 5, wanders over:
Hello Brother Francis.
Hullo, Young Warlock. My, you're growing fast. You must be all of...
Five. I'm five. What’s that?
Brother Sparrow. And here’s Brother Snail... Sister Slug. Remember, Warlock, as you grow, to have love and reverence for all living things.
Nanny says Living things are only fit to be ground under my heels, Brother Francis.
Don’t listen to her. Listen to me. INT. WARLOCK’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Nanny has wound up the SPOOKY MUSIC BOX and the thing tha casts SCARY SHADOWS ON THE WALL. Young Warlock is in bed.  52.
Will you sing me a lullaby, Nanny?
Of course, dear. (sings) Go to sleep and dream of pain/ Doom and darkness, blood and brains/ Sleep so sweet, my darling boy/ You will rule, when Earth's destroyed.
Francis says that I must be kind and nice to everybody. And hug them. Even Brother slug. And not destroy the earth.
Don’t listen to him. Listen to me.
The top deck of a bus. Aziraphale is reading a paper. Cro sits down next to him.
He’s too normal.
Not at all. It’s working. The Heavenly influences are balancing out the hellish. A no score draw.
I hope you’re right. Six years to go.
Cut between Crowley and Aziraphale entering lifts, and pushing buttons for the top floor and the bottom.
Crowley gets out of the lift. He saunters over to recepti Muzak in background.
Er. Crowley. Annual report.  53.
Room Five. Crowley walks down a dull corridor, past identical doors. Door Four opens, and Hastur comes out, along with a blast fire and screams from inside. He’s dusting himself off.
Hastur.
Crowley. They both go through door 5.
It’s an office. It’s shadowy, which is good, as we do not want to see the entities to whom Crowley is reporting in much detail.
Tell uss about the boy Warlock.
He’s a remarkable child.
Is he evil?
Fantastically evil.
Killed anyone yet?
Not yet. But there’s more to evil than just killing people. Vague noises of agreement from hellish entities: Crowley a point.
Yeah. But it’s fun.

We're at the top of a skyscraper, looking out over London Aziraphale’s meeting is very similar. Nicer decor. The incredibly well-dressed, nice men and women he’s talking have faces that seem slightly burned out by light.  54.
And I feel that, on a deep level, the child is being influenced towards the light. By me.
That sounds very commendable. Excellent work, Aziraphale. As usual.
Yes. But Aziraphale. We will be most understanding should you fail. After all, wars are to be won.
Not avoided.
Still. As he likes to say. Climb every mountain.
Ford every stream. And we finish on Aziraphale’s face, as he winces. TITLE CARD: THE PRESENT DAY. TITLE CARD: TUESDAY.
WARLOCK, a couple of days before his 11th birthday, is be dragged about the British Museum by his mother.
Honey. Look. It’s old. And educational.
It’s dumb.
It’s not dumb, sweetie. It’s thumbscrews.
Dumbscrews more like. Can we talk about my birthday party?  55. Mrs Dowling drags him over to the next exhibit. We pull b to see that Crowley and Aziraphale were both watching.
Thumbscrews! What normal kid doesn’t like torture?
But it’s good he’s not interested in torture! Isn’t it?
I don’t know.
So. I hear that your people will be sending him a Hell Hound.
It’s the start of it all. He has to name it: Stalks By Night, or Throat-— Ripper or something. But if we’ve done our job, properly, he’ll send it away, unnamed.
And if he does name it?
Then you and I have lost. He’1l have all his powers, and Armageddon will be just around the corner.
At his birthday party?
Yes.
We should be there. In fact...(He’s just had an idea) I could. Entertain.
No. Please, no.
(wiggling his fingers) I'd just need to get back in practice. Attempts a French Drop with a coin. Drops it. Fumbles aro to pick it up, irritating tourists.  56.

Don’t do this. Please. I am actually begging you, and you have no idea how demeaning that is. Please. EXT. WARLOCK’S PARTY - DAY We are in a huge tent in Warlock’s back garden. It’s a pa Birthday balloons. We have a couple of dozen eleven year olds, all very well dressed. Warlock is wearing an 11 Bad the kind you get off a birthday card. We also have some SECRET SERVICE OFFICERS. The same ones saw eleven years ago, just a little older. We have caterers, all wearing white food-serving jackets, even Crowley, who seems to be in charge of them, and is waiting by the cake. There are trifles and jellies and su Crowley looks down in embarrassment. The Kids all look bewildered -- horrified -- saddened. Because, up on a little stage... It’s AZIRAPHALE! Dressed in the style of a Victorian conjurer, top hat and tails and all, in clothes he bought hundred and fifty years ago and has not work for fifty, a has never dry cleaned, proud as punch.

head_text.subj: THE AMAZING MISTER FELL AND HIS REMARKABLE FEATS OF

text: PRESTIDIGITATION is painted on a peeling old canvas in fr of him. He has a little collapsible table, a magic wand, he’s in heaven. Right now, he’s showing them his hat.

Now you sees my old top hat? Where did you get that hat, as you young uns do say? Well, you also see that there is nothing inside my perfectly normal top hat such as any of you might wear on a trip to the confectioners. But wait! What is this? Could it be our furry friend, Harry the Rabbit? A rabbit is produced from the hat. The kids are unimpress
Dumb. It was in the table.  57.
You said there were going to be cartoons. I got cartoons at my birthday. An I got an Ipad an I got an Iphone an I got a smartwatch an I got a...
You're rubbish.
Excuse me. Excuse me. She’s right, you know. You are actually rubbish. Crowley is looking around for the Black Hound. He looks a the Clock -- 2 minutes to 3. Checks his watch: almost 3..
(pressing on) Do any of you young’uns have such a thing as a thruppeny bit about your persons? No? Well, what’s that behind your ear? Crowley is counting the seconds now. Five, four, three, two...

Hastur and Ligur. They are standing in a huge aircraft-ha like building in Hell. A huge portcullis-like gate behind them. We can’t see the animal in there, but it would appe to be about thirty feet high and terrifying. It GROWLS. They are eyeing it nervously. A DISPOSABLE DEMON near the eyes it with stark terror.
That’s... that’s a hell hound all right.
It’s big.
It’ll be what he wants it to be. You! Get in there. Open the gate!
Me?

You. Yeah. Watch out for his teeth.  58. Hastur and Ligur watch, as the demon vanishes off. Hell H growls. The Sound of a winching gate lifting... Then a SCREAM from the disposable Demon. Hastur and Ligur wince. Sound of a disposable demon being eaten.
It’s not like you didn’t tell him to look out for the teeth.
Point. Now. He’s free to find his master... They look up, scared, as the shadow of something huge goe past them... INT. WARLOCK’S PARTY - DAY Crowley’s watch says 3 pm. Crowley looks around. Nothing.
This sucks.

And for my next remarkable illusion, I will need a pocket handkerchief. A perfectly normal one. Does anyone have a pocket handkerchief? Blank kids. Some of them have pulled out their phones and playing video games.
I do. I really will need a handkerchief. I... He blinks and performs a miracle. Ping! Turns to a Securi Guard...
You, my fine young jack-sauce. If you look in your pocket, I have no doubt you will find a handkerchief.
M’afraid not, sir.

No. You do. Just look. Please look.  59. The guard reaches into his inside pocket, and looks puzzl Then pulls out AN ENORMOUS LACE-EDGED HANKIE which goes n into his pocket, but into his shoulder holster... and whi as he pulls it out, snags his gun. The gun ARCS slowly and gracefully and in slow motion thr the air. It splashes down in a bowl of trifle near Warlock. The kids applaud. This is more like it!
Not bad. Warlock grabs the gun. Covers the room.
Hands up lowlife scumbuckets! I got a gun. A beat. The Guards look around, panicky, and aren’t sure to do...
S'not fair. Why have you got a gun and we don’t?

I’m not stopping you. Girl 1 is next to a Security Guard, and grabs at his gun. The Guard doesn’t quite know how to deal with this. Boy 1 throws a lump of cake at Warlock, who whirls around and reflexively, squeezes the trigger... FREEZE IMAGE.
We are in the Narrator’s World, and the scene is on a big Screen. The Narrator is standing beside it.

The .357 Magnum Hollow point cartridge, coming out of a secret service Sig Sauer P229 at 1,430 feet per second, is capable of blowing anyone away, leaving only a red mist in the air, a messy corpse and a certain amount of paperwork. (MORE )

It would have taken a miracle to avoid a massacre. INT. WARLOCK’S PARTY - DAY Close up on Aziraphale’s face. He does a Miracle Blink, a A STREAM OF WATER comes from the nozzle of Warlock’s gun. Which is now a water pistol. Aziraphale looks rather proud of himself. And then a huge lump of birthday trifle HITS HIM IN THE F Guards are (puzzled) firing water pistol guns. Kids are (enthusiastically) firing water pistol guns. Perfectly timed lumps of jelly and trifle and cake are be thrown around. IT’S A FOOD FIGHT!

Best Eleventh Birthday ever! And through the chaos and the flying food, Crowley walks perfectly unharmed, untouched, barely paying attention to chaos, checking his watch, removing his white caterer’s jacket, and dropping it onto the ground... EXT. WARLOCK’S RESIDENCE - DAY The street outside. Crowley is standing, looking worried. Aziraphale joins him. He’s reaching into his sleeve.
It was all a bit of a mess, I’m afraid.
Nonsense. You gave them all a party to remember. Last one they’1ll ever have, mind... Aziraphale has removed the dove from his sleeve. He’s prodding it, but it’s dead.
It’s late.
Comes of putting it up your sleeve.
No. The Hell Hound. It’s late. Crowley irritably taps the dead dove, which flutters and flies off. He reaches into the Bentley and turns on the radio. It’s JUST A MINUTE...
And you have Just a Minute to tell us all about Fish Fingers starting Hello Crowley. Is sssomething wrong?
Um. Hi. Who’s this?
Dagon. Lord of the Files. Master of Torments.
Yeah. Just checking in about the Hell Hound...
We freed him. He walks to find his master. Is something wrong, Crowley?
Wrong? No.... Nothing’s wrong. What could be wrong? I can see it now. What a lovely big helly hell hound. Hey, great talking to you. He turns off the radio.
No dog.
No dog.
Wrong boy.
Wrong boy. There’s a gunshot.
(not swearing) Oh sugar! I must have missed one. 61.  62.
Armageddon is days away. And we've lost the Antichrist. Get in. Aziraphale just stands there, shocked.
How can you lose the Antichrist?
They are both shocked.
You said it was him.
It was him. I should know. I delivered the baby. Not delivered- delivered it. You know. Handed it over.
Someone else must be interfering, then.
Who? There isn’t anyone else. There’s good, that’s your lot. There’s evil. That’s mine. One side or the other. And between us, we've lost the antichrist.
I can’t believe it. Even Heaven was certain that the Hell Hound would be showing up today.
It was sent. And the boy was meant to have named it. You have to name the beast: it gives it its purpose and its function. It’1l be stalks by night, or throat-ripper or something.
Perhaps he won’t name it.
He’1ll name it. I’m screwed. Do you know what they can do to you down there?  63.
The same sort of thing they can do to you up there.
Yeah, but you lot get ineffable mercy.
Remember Sodom and Gomorrah? That was my team.
Oh, the good times. There was a little bar you could get a fermented date palm cocktail...
I mean, after. (pause) So if that appalling child wasn’t the antichrist, where in blessed blazes is he? And where’s the Hell Hound? And what do we do?
Still a beautiful little village in England. We are movin through it. The clock on the village steeple is striking Three.

Look! There’s a sort of an abandoned quarry down there, through the bushes. It’s a perfect place for kids to play area of natural beauty that adults have forgotten. And there’s a lane above it. Birds are singing. A lazy bumble bee buzzes in the flower the side of the lane. Down in the quarry we can see CHILDREN, four of them, all about eleven, playing. They are a gang of Four, called The Them, and we will mee them next episode. They look harmless and sweet and VULNERABLE...  64. And one of them is swinging down a rope, in a repeat of t Zip-Line incident, only rather more successful: Golden- haired, glorious, the ultimate 11 year old. It MUST be AD And now we hear something, as the last of the bell chimes fades away. Something metallic and disturbing, rumbling a nightmarish. A ripping, rumbling noise, and now, LOOK! There’s a beat in front of us, on the lane, appears, from Hell -- THE HELL HOUND. If we can, this should be a REAL big black dog, possibly enhanced. It’s huge: a terrifying monster of a dog. The H of the Baskervilles would take one look at this brute and flee, whimpering. The Dog’s eyes are glowing red. It drip saliva. It looks at the kids below, hungrily and evilly... And it opens its mouth and GROWLS terrifyingly, showing h and awful teeth as we - FADE TO BLACK. OVER END CREDITS, BUDDY HOLLY’S “EVERY DAY”, THIS TIME DO BY A BOYS’ CHOIR, IN THE STYLE OF CARMINA BURANA.
